journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering

title-group.article-title: A local adaptive differential quadrature method for solving multi-dimensional heat transport equation at the microscale

article-meta.aff: Department of Applied Mathematics, National Chung Hsing University, Taichung, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Jiun-Yu Wu, Department of Applied Mathematics, National Chung Hsing University, Taichung 40227, Taiwan. Email: adherelinux@hotmail.com

abstract.p: In this article, we employed the local adaptive differential quadrature method to solve multi-dimensional heat transport equation at the microscale. The local adaptive differential quadrature method was employed to tackle the boundary conditions by using both localized interpolation basis functions and exterior grid points. We found that accurate numerical solution can be obtained by using a small number of gird points for boundary treatments. The governing equation of heat transport was employed to describe the thermal behavior of microstructures, which was of vital importance in microtechnology applications. Four examples showed the effectiveness and accuracy of our algorism in providing excellent estimates of unknown temperature from the given data. We found that the proposed scheme is applicable to the heat transport equation at the microscale.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The semiconductor manufacturing process produces many electronic products that can be still be miniaturized, to facilitate faster and better functioning, for example: computers, mobile phones, IC and others. Surface treatment is important for many semiconductor industries for improving new materials and enhancingproduction technologies. On the other hand, thin film deposition is usually used for surface treatment method which is applied to tools, heat treatment, coatings, semiconductor components, and others. However, the effect of temperature on rates of reaction is a significant factor. Hence, heat transport at the microscale is of vital importance for the surface treatment processes.1,2 We usually use the mathematical model to describe the physical phenomena. In general, the partial differentiation equation describes a physical phenomenon in the engineering and science, for example, the Navier–Stokes equation, the heat conduction equation, the vibration equation, the wave equation and so forth. In the last decades, Özisik and Tzou proposed one-dimensional heat transport equation to describe the physical properties of microstructure.3,4 Dai et al.5 used a compact finite-difference scheme for a one-dimensional heat transport equation and they obtained good results. Dai et al.6 developed a compact finite difference scheme for the three-dimensional heat transport equation in a thin film. They considered a small scale in the z-direction and showed the Fourier analysis method was unconditionally stable.

The differential quadrature method (DQM) was proposed by Bellman et al.7,8 The method is widely used in solving various engineering and scientific problems, such as vibration mechanics9,10 and fluid mechanics.11–13 The DQM has some oscillation problem when the domain uses a lot of grid points. Therefore, Wang et al.14 proposed to improve the DQM by using fictitious points. The La-DQM is mainly used for solving high-order differential equations that arise in an eigenvalue problem and a boundary value problem. Char et al.15 used the La-DQM to solve the effects of viscous dissipation on slip-flow heat transfer in a micro annulus.

Recently, Zhao et al.16 proposed a matched interface and boundary method (MIB), which is the most stable and accurate method, to tackle various boundary conditions. Also, stability properties of numerical methods have been discussed in their paper. Zhao et al.17 also used MIB to solve the vibration analysis of plates. Harfash18 employed high accuracy finite difference scheme to solve the two- and three-dimensional microscale heat transport equation with second-order accuracy for time and space and then developed a compact scheme, fourth order in space and second order in time. Srivastava et al.19 modified homotopy perturbation method to solve three-dimensional time fractional microscale heat transport equation and obtained desirable results. They thought that the HPM was more easy and user friendly in comparison with the high accuracy finite difference scheme. In the last few years, Malek et al.20 employed a mixed collocation-finite difference method to tackle 3D microscopic heat transport problems and then considered the temperature distribution both inside and on the particle’s surface. Heidari et al.21 proposed a closed-form analytic solution which was a linear and time-independent partial differential equation. Besides, they showed that the closed form is described by a semigroup, characterized the heat distribution in a thin film, and obtained a basis of eigenfunctions.

In this article, we consider the multi-dimensional heat transport equation at the microscale and employ the La-DQM to tackle it. We find that the scheme is applicable to the multi-dimensional heat transport equation and obtain accurate results. We demonstrate that La-DQM performs very well in solving heat transport problems. The article is summarized as follows. In section ‘Formulation of the heat transport equation,’ we present the multi-dimensional heat transport equation. Then, we explain the La-DQM theory in ‘Differential quadrature method’, and use the La-DQM to discretize the governing equation. ‘Numerical examples’ section shows four examples to estimate the unknown temperature item. Finally, we draw some important conclusions in the last section.

sec.title: Formulation of the heat transport equation
sec.p: First, we consider the one-dimensional heat transport equation,5 which is given by the following equation τqα∂2u(x,t)∂t2+1α∂u(x,t)∂t=∂2u(x,t)∂x2+τT∂3u(x,t)∂t∂x2+G in (1)Ω, (x,t)∈Ω:=[0,ℓ]×[0,T].

Second, we contemplate the two-dimensional heat transport equation τqα∂2u(x,y,t)∂t2+1α∂u(x,y,t)∂t =τq∂3u(x,y,t)∂t∂x2+τT∂3u(x,y,t)∂t∂y2+∂2u(x,y,t)∂x2 +∂2u(x,y,t)∂y2+G in (2)Ω,(x,y,t)∈Ω:=[0,a]×[0,b]×[0,T]

Third, the following three-dimensional heat transport equation6 is deliberated τqα∂2u(x,y,z,t)∂t2+1α∂u(x,y,z,t)∂t =τq(∂3u(x,y,z,t)∂t∂x2+∂3u(x,y,z,t)∂t∂y2) +τT∂3u(x,y,z,t)∂t∂z2+∂2u(x,y,z,t)∂x2 +∂2u(x,y,z,t)∂y2+∂2u(x,y,z,t)∂z2+G in (3)Ω,(x,y,z,t)∈Ω:=[0,a]×[0,b]×[0,c]×[0,T] (4)u=uBonΓB, (5)u=uionΓi. where G=1K[Q+τq∂Q∂t],α is the thermal diffusively. τT and τq are positive constants that are the temperature gradient and time lags of the heat flux, respectively. u is to be determined. We take a bounded domain D in Rj, j = 1, 2, 3 and a spacetime domain Ω=D×(0,t) in Rj+1 for a time t > 0, and write two surfaces ΓB=∂D×[0,t] and Γi=∂D×{t} of the boundary ∂Ω. While equations (1) to (5) constitute a j-dimensional heat transport equations for the given boundary data uB:ΓB→R and the initial data ui:Γi→R.

sec.title: Differential quadrature method
sec.p: We ponder over a one-dimensional function f(x) on the area a≤x≤b. To approximate the derivate of a smooth function at a discrete point xi in the domain, the DQM7 employs the weighted linear sum of all function values at all discrete points in the x direction. Then, the mth-order derivatives f(x) with respect to xi at point i can be formulated as (6)dmf(xi)dxm=∑i=1NCi,jmf(xj),i=1,…,N. where f(xj) are the function values at the jth sampling point xj, N is the number of discrete points, and Ci,jm are the unknown weighting coefficients of the mth order derivative at discrete point xi, in which m≤N-1.

Shu and Richards11,12 provided a convenient and recurrent formula for determining the following derivative weighting coefficients (7)Ci,j1=M(xi)(xi-xj)·M(xj),fori≠j,andi,j=1,…,N, (8)Ci,jm=m·[Ci,jm-1·Ci,j1-Ci,jm-1(xi-xj)], for2≤m≤N-1,andi,j=1,…,N, (9)Ci,jm=-∑j=1i≠jNCi,jm,for1≤m≤N-1andi=1,…,N. where (10)M(xi)=Πj=1,i≠jN(xi-xj).
Note that in accordance with the principle of the DQM, the locations of the sampling grid point xi can be arbitrarily determined. The La-DQM of conception is as follows:

The weighting coefficients of the first derivatives is given by (11)Ci,j[1]=gi,j[1](xi)forj=-Li,…,Ri;j≠0, and for j = 0 (12)Ci,0[1]=-∑j=-Li,j≠0RiCi,j[1]. where (13)gi,j(x)=Πk=i-Li,k≠i+ji+Rix-xkxi+j-xkforj=-Li,…,Ri.

We can computer the weighting coefficients of the higher order derivatives by a recurrence formula (14)Ci,j[m]=m(Ci,j[1]Ci,j(m-1)-Ci,j(m-1)xi-xi+j), j=-Li,…,Ri;j≠0, and for j = 0 (15)Ci,0[m]=-∑j=-Li,j≠0RiCi,j[m].

sec.title: Numerical examples
sec.p: We employ the La-DQM to solve multi-dimensional heat transport with temperature through four examples. We apply the quadrature rule to get a vector matrix form (16){A}{u}={B}
Here, we use Matlab software to solve this linear equation (16).

sec.title: Example 1
sec.p: Let us ponder over another one-dimensional heat transport equation5 (17)32π2∂2u(x,t)∂t2+12∂u(x,t)∂t=∂2u(x,t)∂x2+2π2∂3u(x,t)∂t∂x2, 0≤x≤ℓ,t>0.
In this article, we choose ℓ=1, t=1 and the exact solution is (18)u(x,t)=e-π2tsin(πx),0≤x≤ℓ,t>0.
The initial and boundary conditions are (19)u(x,0)=0,∂u(x,0)∂t=0 and (20)u(0,t)=0,u(ℓ,t)=0

Using the quadrature rule for equation (17) the following algebraic equation can be obtained (21)32π2∑m=1MDj,m[2]u(xi,tm)+12∑m=1MDj,m[1]u(xi,tm) =∑n=1NCi,n[2]u(xn,tl)+2π2∑m=1MDj,m[1]∑n=1NCi,n[2]u(xn,tm). Where Ci,n[2] is the weighting coefficients of second-order derivative at discrete point xi, Dj,m[2] is the weighting coefficients of the second-order derivative at discrete time tj, and so on and so forth. With a little algebra, we can rearrange the equation (21) to solve for u(x,t) variables. (23)X=[u(x1,t1)……u(xN,tM)]T. (24)B=[0……0]T.

Under the following parameters: ℓ=1, N = 21, Δx = 1/20, T = 1, M = 31 and Δt = 1/30. Figure 1 displays the exact and numerical results with different of grid points N = 11, 21 and 41. The maximal absolute error is about 3.068 × 10−10. We calculated the error of the numerical solution as follows (25)Error=(Δx∑i=1N|(uexact)in-(unumerical)in|2)12. Figure 1.
The exact solutions and numerical solutions for Example 1 with different of grid points N = 11, 21, 41.

Figure 2 shows the error of the numerical solutions for Example 1 with grid points N = 41. From Figure 1, the present results are also better than that calculated by Dai et al.5 To the authors’ best knowledge, there has been no open literature about the numerical methods calculating this heat transport equation well as the La-DQM. Figure 2.
Error of the numerical solutions for Example 1 with grid points N = 41.

sec.title: Example 2
sec.p: Let us consider another one-dimensional heat transport equation (26)(1π+100)∂2u(x,t)∂t2+∂u(x,t)∂t=∂2u(x,t)∂x2 +(1π2+10-6)∂3u(x,t)∂t∂x2,0≤x≤10-4,t>0. Where the exact solution is (27)u(x,t)=e-π2tsin(πx),0≤x≤10-4,t>0.
The initial and boundary conditions are (28)u(x,0)=0,∂u(x,0)∂t=0 and (29)u(0,t)=0,u(10-4,t)=e-π2tsin(10-4π).

Using the quadrature rule for equation (26) the following algebraic equation can be obtained (30)(1π2+100)∑m=1MDj,m[2]u(xi,tm)+∑m=1MDj,m[1]u(xi,tm) =∑n=1NCi,n[2]u(xn,tl)+(1π2+10-6) ×∑m=1MDj,m[1]∑n=1NCi,n[2]u(xn,tm).
We can apply equations (22) to (24) for assembly {A} matrix, {X} vector and {B} vector.

Where Ci,n[2] is the weighting coefficients of the second-order derivative at discrete point xi, Dj,m[2] is the weighting coefficients of the second-order derivative at discrete time tj, and so on and so forth.

Under the following parameters: N = 11, Δx = 1/20, T = 1, M = 71 and Δt = 1/70. Figure 3 displays the exact solutions and numerical solutions with different of grid points N = 11, 21 and 41. The maximal absolute error is about 1.84 × 10−7. We calculated the error of the numerical solution as follows (31)Error=(110-4Δx∑i=1N|(uexact)in-(unumerical)in|2)12 Figure 3.
The exact solutions and numerical solutions for Example 2 with different of grid points N = 11, 21, 41.

Figure 4 shows the error of the numerical solutions for Example 2 with grid points N = 41. From this figure, we can say that the method is more accurate than that calculated by Dai et al.5 Figure 4.
Error of the numerical solutions for Example 2 with grid points N = 41.

sec.title: Example 3
sec.p: Let us consider the two-dimensional heat transport equation (32)(1π+100)∂2u(x,y,t)∂t2+∂u(x,y,t)∂t=∂2u(x,y,t)∂x2 +∂2u(x,y,t)∂y2+(1π2+100)∂3u(x,y,t)∂t∂x2 +(1π2+10-6)∂3u(x,y,t)∂t∂y2 Where the exact solution is (33)u(x,y,t)=e-π2tsin(πx)sin(104πy),0≤x≤a, 0≤y≤b,0≤t≤T

The initial and boundary conditions are (34)u(x,y,0)=sin(πx)sin(104πy),∂u(x,y,0)∂t=-π2sin(πx)sin(104πy) and (35)u(0,y,t)=0,u(a,y,t)=e-π2tsin(πa)sin(104πy) (36)u(x,0,t)=0,u(x,b,t)=e-π2tsin(πx)sin(104πb)

Using the quadrature rule for equation (32) the following algebraic equation can be obtained (37)(1π2+100)∑q=1QEk,p[2]u(xi,yj,tq)+∑q=1QEk,p[1]u(xi,yj,tq) =∑n=1NCi,n[2]u(xn,yj,tk)+∑m=1MDj,m[2]u(xi,ym,tk) +(1π2+100)∑q=1QEk,q[1]∑n=1NCi,n[2]u(xn,yj,tq) +(1π2+10-6)∑q=1QEk,q[1]∑m=1MDj,m[2]u(xi,ym,tk).
We can apply equations (22) to (24) for assembly {A} matrix, {X} vector and {B} vector.

Where Ci,n[2] is the weighting coefficients of the second-order derivative at discrete point xi, Dj,m[2] is the weighting coefficients of the second-order derivative at discrete point yi, Ek,q[2] is the weighting coefficients of the second-order derivative at discrete time tk, and so on and so forth.

We first choose a = 1, b = 10−4, T = 1, N = 11, M = 11, Q = 11, Δx = 1/10, Δy = 10−5 and Δt = 1/10. Figure 5 displays the exact solutions and Figure 6 shows numerical solutions. We calculated the error of the numerical solution as follows (38)Error=(110-4ΔxΔy∑i,j=1N|(uexact)i,jn-(unumerical)i,jn|2)12 Figure 5.
The exact solutions for Example 3 of two-dimensional heat transport problem.
Figure 6.
The La-DQM solutions for Example 3 of two-dimensional heat transport problem.

Figure 7 shows the absolute error. In the project, the maximal absolute error is about 4.86 × 10−6. For this problem, the La-DQM shows good results. Figure 7.
Error of the numerical solutions for Example 3.

sec.title: Example 4
sec.p: In the problem, we first introduce the operator as follows (39)∇2u(x,y,z,t)=∂2u(x,y,z,t)∂x2+∂2u(x,y,z,t)∂y2+∂2u(x,y,z,t)∂z2

Let us consider three-dimensional heat transport equation in a thin film6 (40)(1π+100)∂2u(x,y,z,t)∂t2+∂u(x,y,z,t)∂t =∇2u(x,y,z,t)+(1π2+100){∂3u(x,y,z,t)∂t∂x2+∂3u(x,y,z,t)∂t∂y2} +(1π2+10-6)∂3u(x,y,z,t)∂t∂z2.

We describe the thin film that is as shown in Figure 11. Figure 8.
The exact solutions for Example 4 of three-dimensional heat transport problem. Figure 9.
The La-DQM solutions for Example 4 of three-dimensional heat transport problem. Figure 10.
Error of the numerical solutions for Example 4. Figure 11.
Three-dimensional thin film sketch.
Where the exact solution is (41)u(x,y,t)=e-π2tsin(πx)sin(πy)sin(104πz), 0≤x≤a,0≤y≤b,0≤z≤c,0≤t≤T

The initial and boundary conditions are (42)u(x,y,z,0)=sin(πx)sin(πy)sin(104πz),∂u(x,y,z,0)∂t=-π2sin(πx)sin(πy)sin(104πz) and (43)u(0,y,z,t)=0,u(a,y,z,t)=e-π2t ×sin(πa)sin(πy)sin(104πz) (44)u(x,0,z,t)=0,u(0,b,z,t)=e-π2t ×sin(πx)sin(πb)sin(104πz) (45)u(x,y,0,t)=0,u(x,y,c,t)=e-π2t ×sin(πx)sin(πy)sin(104πc)

Using the quadrature rule for equation (40) the following algebraic equation can be obtained (46)(1π2+100)∑q=1QFl,p[2]u(xi,yj,zk,tq) +∑q=1QFl,p[1]u(xi,yj,zk,tq)=∑n=1NCi,n[2]u(xn,yj,zk,tq) +∑m=1MDj,m[2]u(xi,ym,zk,tl)+∑h=1HEk,h[2]u(xi,yj,zh,tl) +(1π2+100){∑q=1QFl,q[1]∑n=1NCi,n[2]u(xn,yj,zh,tq) +∑q=1QFl,q[1]∑m=1MDj,m[2]u(xi,ym,zk,tl)} +(1π2+10-6)∑q=1QFl,q[1]∑h=1HEk,h[2]u(xi,yj,zh,tl).
We can apply type of equations (22) to (24) for assembly {A} matrix, {X} vector and {B} vector.

Where Ci,n[2] is the weighting coefficients of the second-order derivative at discrete point xi, Dj,m[2] is the weighting coefficients of the second-order derivative at discrete point yi, Ek,h[2] is the weighting coefficients of the second-order derivative at discrete time zk, Fl,q[2] is the weighting coefficients of the second-order derivative at discrete time tl, and so on and so forth.

Under the following parameters: a = b = 1, c = 10−4, N = M = H = Q = 11, Δx = Δy = 1/10, Δz = 10−4, Δt = 1/10 and T = 1. Figures 8 and 9 exhibit the exact, numerical results, and Figure 10 shows the absolute error. We calculated the error of the numerical solution as follows (47)Error=(110-4ΔxΔy∑i,j,k=1N|(uexact)i,j,kn-(unumerical)i,j,kn|2)12.
For this problem, the La-DQM proposed here is still good with a maximum error 6.91 × 10−5. We can say that the method can tackle muti-dimensional heat transport equations through this example.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, by employing the La-DQM, we can very well estimate the multi-dimensional heat transport equation at the microscale with high-order accuracy. Four numerical experiments of the heat transport problem are worked out, which shows that our proposed approach is applicable to the ill-posed problem. The numerical errors of our scheme are in the order of O(10−5)–O(10−10). Moreover, those effects are very significant in the computations of three-dimensional problem. Therefore, it can be concluded that the La-DQM is a stable, accurate, and an effective method.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Department of Applied Mathematics, National Chung Hsing University.
